posts.post_content: Besides the obvious implications for Bant Hexproof, I think this has the potential to be the best enemy hoser in the cycle. It's effect isn't as immediately valuable as [Lifebane Zombie](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Lifebane Zombie)'s, but it starts as a 3/3 for 3, can't be removed except by a sweeper, and can grow past its already considerable stats if the opponent gets desperate.
posts.html:

posts.post_content:
THIS THING! This is what I see in my nightmares! A well costed, on curve, unremovable monster that just grows and grows and grows...  
I keep thinking I can just [Doom Blade](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Doom Blade) it whenever I see it, then I see the hexproof. Its not even like [Lifebane Zombie](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Lifebane Zombie) can deal with it, since with [Elvish Mystic](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Elvish Mystic) this drops on turn 2. At least the zombie has a late-game upside, but... man, green just keeps getting crazier.

posts.post_content:
A 3/3 with hexproof is good by itself, and its ability will make control decks cry. I don't expect for it to see that much constructed play because the GG will be hard to pull off, but I think that it is definitely possible. With [Invisble Stalker](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Invisble Stalker) and [Gesit of Saint Traft](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Gesit of Saint Traft) cycling out I think that Bant Hexproof could use some more creatures.  
  
4.5/5
posts.html:

posts.post_content: While I like this card a lot, I don't think Witchstalker is going to make as big a splash as people have been saying. Remember that it only powers up when your opponent plays Blue and Black spells on ***your*** turn. It's still valuable as a deterrent from other players using counterspells to screw up your combos, and will most certainly make it onto many a sideboard, but it's pretty niche otherwise.
posts.html:
